title: Railway signalman may have played key role in the Great Train Robbery
text:
A railway signalman may have played a key role in the Great Train Robbery, according to a former British Transport Police detective.

Thomas Wyn-De-Bank was on duty in a signal box near to where the famous heist happened in the early hours of August 8, 1963, Graham Satchwell reveals in his new book.

Wyn-De-Bank had a criminal past that Satchwell believes the gang may have used to coerce him into helping the plot, which saw robbers raid the Glasgow to Euston mail train and seize more than £2million.

Thomas Wyn-De-Bank (pictured)was on duty in a signal box near to where the famous heist happened in the early hours of August 8, 1963, Graham Satchwell reveals in his new book

In Great Train Robbery Confidential, Mr Satchwell identified inconsistencies in the statements the signalman gave to police after the heist, which was pulled off by a gang that included Ronnie Biggs, Charlie Wilson and Tommy Wisbey.

He also failed to follow proper procedure after the robbery gang tampered with a light to show a red signal, forcing the driver to stop.

No calls were made to alert authorities when the hijacked train was divided further down the line, nor did he raise the alarm when the robbers were escaping with sacks of cash.

Great Train robber Ronnie Biggs

Mr Satchwell writes of the suspect, who served time in prison for bigamy: 'Why was he so negligent? Why didn't he do his job? It seems to me there are only two possible reasons.

'Firstly, he might have willingly taken part in the robbery. If that is the case, then he was obviously hopelessly ill-prepared for the British Rail enquiry.

'Once the enquiry was overcome his only remaining hurdle would be to give evidence at the trial where his deceit might be uncovered.'

Despite Mr Satchell's suspicions, there is little evidence of Wyn-De-Bank suddenly becoming rich after the robbery.

His son, Charlie, said the family received new bikes a few months after the event, but there were few luxuries later on.

During the heist a gang stopped the Glasgow-Euston overnight mail train as it passed through the Buckinghamshire countryside close to Cheddington.

The train was driven a mile and a half to the bridge where the criminals unloaded £2,631,684 in used notes.

But they were later captured and 12 were jailed for a total of more than 300 years.

The getaway cars are parked under the bridge which were used to take minor roads back to Leatherslade Farm

Detectives at Cheddington Station inspect coupling of one of the coaches of the Glasgow-Euston travelling post office

Mr Satchwell has also claimed in his book that the notorious Kray twins were linked to the plot.

The Krays were known for their business dealings in London, but the author says they also spread up to Glasgow too - where the fateful train started its journey.

Mr Satchwell said the brothers were in cahoots with Scottish gangster Arthur Thompson from at least 1963 - the year of the robbery - and Ronnie had 'mysterious' flying visits to the city that year.

He wrote: 'Importantly, Ronnie Kray flew to Glasgow several times in 1963 to meet with Glasgow gangsters.'
